awd_titl_txt: Understanding and Engineering the Nucleation of Enzyme Metal-Organic Frameworks
awd_abstract_narration:
Enzymes are natural catalysts that can be used by chemical industries to speed up the rate of reactions and reduce the energy requirements of catalytic processes. However, enzymes are not typically stable outside of the physiological environment in which they evolved, significantly limiting their utility for industrial applications. A potential solution to this problem is to immobilize enzymes onto support structures. The ideal support material must be capable of loading high quantities of the active form of the enzyme. The support should also increase the stability and recyclability of the enzyme compared to the free enzyme in solution. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a promising class of materials for enzyme immobilization. MOFs are porous crystalline materials formed by the self-assembly of metal ions and organic ligands. Enzymes can be immobilized on MOFs by simply mixing the metal, ligand, and enzyme in aqueous solutions at room temperature. The enzymes are then incorporated into the MOF framework during the nucleation and growth processes. Understanding how this process works requires a detailed analysis of the system's nucleation and growth mechanisms. This fundamental mechanistic knowledge will provide robust design rules for the synthesis of enzyme-immobilized MOFs with high loading of the active form of the enzyme. The ability to immobilize practically any enzyme at the MOF surface has the potential to revolutionize the biotechnology industry and benefit society through lower energy chemical processes. The investigator will also develop a mobile K-12 outreach activity that uses low-cost microscopy to observe salt crystal growth. 

This project aims to determine the nucleation and growth mechanisms of enzyme MOF composite materials. The approach employs cryogenic and liquid-phase electron microscopy. Cryogenic electron microscopy will be used to trap intermediates and analyze their high-resolution structure. Liquid-phase electron microscopy will be used to monitor the kinetics of absorption, nucleation, and growth. The electron microscopy data will be supported by bulk scattering analysis using light and X-rays. The knowledge gained from these mechanistic studies will be used to re-engineer the interfacial chemistry to improve both encapsulation efficiency and enzymatic activity. The project will reveal the formation mechanisms, how the mechanisms can be manipulated by tuning the interfacial chemistry, and the structure-property relationships.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview:This project focused on investigating and improving the interactions between enzymes and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), which are essential materials for catalytic applications. By encapsulating enzymes within MOFs, we can enhance enzyme stability and activity, enabling significant advances in energy-efficient industrial processes like drug development and food production. Our goal was to determine how these enzymes interact with MOFs during formation, particularly understanding how conditions like precursor ratios affect enzyme activity within MOFs.Intellectual Merit:The research established new insights into the role of enzyme folding and its impact on MOF formation and catalytic performance. Using techniques such as cryoTEM and light and x-ray scattering, we observed how different metal-ligand conditions and other synthesis parameters influenced MOF crystal formation and enzyme stability. A major breakthrough was our development of a method to visualize and quantify enzyme location within the MOF at high resolution, which has previously been a challenging aspect in enzyme-MOF research. This project has advanced our understanding of the molecular mechanics of enzyme-MOF interactions, offering a framework for designing enzyme-MOF composites with tailored properties for various applications.Broader Impacts:The outcomes of this research can significantly reduce energy demands in industrial processes by enhancing enzyme stability and reuse in challenging conditions. Additionally, this work supports sustainability by advancing the design of biocomposites that can function in energy-efficient catalytic applications. The project provided valuable training and research experience for undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral researchers, enhancing their skills in advanced microscopy, MOF synthesis, and enzyme analysis. Moreover, findings were disseminated through presentations at national conferences, contributing to the scientific community’s understanding of enzyme-material interactions.Key Findings:Mechanistic Pathways and Activity: We demonstrated that precursor ratios (e.g., HmIm) influence the activity of enzymes such as catalase and glucose oxidase (GOx) within MOFs. Lower ratios led to enhanced enzyme encapsulation and activity, while higher ratios resulted in inactive structures.Visualization Techniques: We developed methods for cryoTEM and dry-state cryo-electron tomography (dry-cryoET) to map enzyme distribution within MOFs, leading to unprecedented insight into how enzyme locations affect catalysis.Enhanced Catalytic Function: The team created a scalable method for synthesizing carbonate-containing MOFs, which integrates enzymes without losing activity, making these composites practical for industrial use.Conclusion:This research provides a foundation for designing highly effective enzyme-MOF biocomposites tailored to specific catalytic applications. By developing and applying novel characterization techniques, the project contributed both fundamental and applied knowledge on enzyme stability, activity, and MOF formation pathways. Continued development of enzyme-MOF technologies could see broader applications in sustainable industrial processes, thereby helping to meet global energy challenges.
